The pulse is quicker in young than in old subjects,
because the former are more irritable than
the latter; upon which principle it is, that the
pulse is continually quicker in weak than in robust
persons*. In a new-born infant the pulse-is
about 134 in a minute; in middle age from 60
to 80; in extreme old age from 50 to 24. In
Greenland, the body is exposed, during long
winters, to such cold, that the pulse is reduced
to 40 or 50 strokes in a minute.
To the circulation of the blood, rightly and
equally performed, we are indebted for life,
health, and at last gradual decay. But if by any
means the blood in its rotatory motion should be
impeded or disturbed, it will become the fruitful
cause of diseases and death. So long as the blood
and humours of the body are in circulation, life
